bibl.title: Junichi Yamamoto v. Luther Weedin. Memo of Authorities Submitted by Government

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
NORTHERN DIVISION
MEMO OF AUTHORITIES SUBMITTED BY GOVERNMENT
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF JUNICHI YAMAMOTO FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS

It appears that petitioner on or about September 17, 1917, being at said time a member of the crew, a seaman, on the steamship TAIYO MARU deserted said steamship at Seattle, Washington, and ever since said date had been in the United States. It appears from the record and from the petitioner's testimony that at no time was petitioner in possession of a passport from the Japanese Government. It further appears that he never presented himself for admission into the United States, and his subsequent residence here has been, without dispute, clandestine and surrepitious.
Section 19 of the Immigration Act, (Act of Feb. 5, 1917), provides:

"That at any time within five years after entry, any alien who at the time of entry was a member of one or more of the classes excluded by law; any alien who shall have entered or who shall be found in the United States in violation of this act, or in vio- lation of any other law of the United States; *****"

Within five years after petitioner's surrepitious entry in the United States, he was arrested by the United States immigration officials, under a warrant of arrest issued by the Secretary of Labor, and was given a hearing before immigrant inspector at Seattle, upon the charges in said warrant. The record of said hearing was forwarded to Washington, and

upon such record the Secretary of Labor decided that petitioner was in the United States in violation of the immigrantion laws of the United States, to wit, in violation of fule 11 of the immigration rules, in violation of the President's Proclamation dated February 24, 1913, in violation of the "Gentlemen's Agreement" between the United States and Japan, and was further a member of an excluded class, to wit, that at the time of his entry he was a person likely to become a public charge.

Upon such findings the Secretary of Labor thereafter issued his warrant of deportation, which warrant is fully set out in the return filed herein, and it is upon the basis of this warrant that the petitioner is detained by the Immigration Commissioner and held for deportation to Japan.

Under the President's Proclamation referred to, and under the"Gentlemen's Agreement", and under rule 11 of the immigration laws, there is no dispute that the petitioner entered the United States in violation of this provision of the law and in that at the time of his entry he was a laborer, skilled or unskilled, and had no passport issued by the Japanese Government. He was therefore a member of an excluded class; and this proceeding falls squarely under the portion of Section 19 of the Immigration Act referred to.

The facts in the case of AKIRA ONO versus United States, M 267 Fed. 359, (C.C.A.9th Circ.) are identical with the facts in this case, and in the case the Circuit Court held that the petitioner was subject to deportation as having deserted his vessel and entered the United States clandestinely, without a passport from the Japanese Government, he being at the time of his entry a laborer, skilled or unskilled. Without quoting
Ms E-
Will you please present this Order in the morning June, Marshal wants to get mid of the boat leaking, and the sale price wa good.
from this case, it is sufficient to say that it clearly covers the case at bar and is conclusive of all contentions made by the petitioner.

Your Honor's attention is further invited to four recent cases decided by Your Honor, the facts in all of which cases are absolutely identical with the facts in the present case, and in all of which recent cases Your Honor, following the Ono case supra, denied the writ. These cases are as follows:
NISHIKAWA MAMORU, No. 6414 (check mark)
IWAMATUS MATSURO, No. 6415 (check mark)
EIJI FUKUNAGA, No. 6435 - p. 517
SHIZO MATSUKAWA, No. 6438. (check mark)
Respectfully submitted.
Thomas P. Revelle
United States Attorney
Judson F. Falkner
Assistant United States Attorney
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
Northern DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF JUNICHI YAMAMOTO FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
MEMO OF AUTHORITIES SUBMITTED BY GOVERNMENT
